page.title: 01THE VILLAGE OF MARSHFIELD
page.content: This compact grey stone village lies in the countryside 600ft high in the South Cotswolds. The main street, from medieval church to the Almshouses a mile to the west, is lined with a continuous frontage of houses, none alike. A school with belfry, 3 inns, shops, businesses, surgery and Post Office are scattered among them. Private housing estates are confined on the north by the 1967 Bypass. There is a council estate and recreation ground. To the south, stone walled fields slope down to St. Catherine's Valley. This area is farmland, mainly grazing and arable, with some woodland. In the small, closely knit, friendly and active community newcomers, many of whom commute to Bath or Bristol, soon become integrated.
